Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Source repo is listed as dependent repo" (#9441) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

If you go to https://www.nuget.org/packages/Enums.NET, you will see that the source repo is listed in Github repo list.



### Repro Steps

Go to https://www.nuget.org/packages/Enums.NET, scroll down to the Github repo list section.

### Expected Behavior

The source repo should not be listed as depdenent repo.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/772561/227658376-5040206d-be84-4557-a1c0-e1cdf091640b.png)

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Add a verified domain adornment similar to VS Marketplace " (#9437) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Currently, we have a blue checkmark which is essentially ID prefix reservation. The requirements for this blue checkmark are outlined here: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/id-prefix-reservation.

We could enhance this flow or add a parallel verification flow that requires ownership of a DNS name. For well-recognized domain names, like "microsoft.com" or "newtonsoft.com" this could allow the associated package author to advertise this relationship (between the package owner and the domain name) and provide one more factor for package consumers to evaluate the trustworthiness of the package.



### The Elevator Pitch

Add a "verified domain" badge to NuGet.org and NuGet client experiences (e.g. VS PM UI). It would probably look like the VS Marketplace experience on their website and in VS Code:

## VS Marketplace search
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/227247994-a6cc3994-1f33-403e-b6c3-55bf7b6e5db8.png)

## VS Marketplace extension details
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/227248034-f7a69c02-2dad-4adf-a5cb-a9a9f6350c08.png)

## VS Code search
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/227248221-6c1a8fbb-7ee4-4895-94a5-51b4fabb499c.png)

## VS Code extension details
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/227248599-2ce71602-18e1-4440-ab07-d3419482d949.png)


### Additional Context and Details

VS Marketplace verification steps:
https://code.visualstudio.com/api/working-with-extensions/publishing-extension#verify-a-publisher

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Prefix reservation C and c is not same." (#9434) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

I have problem with publish package, I think in this case should be allow verify with user like : 

- Prefix  is `Chuongmep` also same with `chuongmep` because this username can't create by another account 
For instance, my package publish is Chuongmep.* but it can't because my user name is chuongmep.



### Repro Steps

Step to make this mistake; 
- Create a user name like : helloword
- Publish package with prefix is Helloword

### Expected Behavior

It should be accept for this case

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31106432/226303836-31737b41-1ad8-4759-b42f-a5e8cbd4c251.png)

### Additional Context and logs
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Chuongmep.Navis.Api.AdWindows

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Warn package authors when a known vulnerability is detected through package verification." (#9436) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

When a package author is uploading a package to NuGet.org, we should validate that it supports up-to-date dependencies through a vulnerability scan which brings awareness to the author of any top-level or transitive dependencies that may be resolved from the consumer side containing a known vulnerability.

If a package dependency or transitive dependency contains a known vulnerability, a security banner may appear to provide more information about the vulnerability and any remediation steps such as including an up-to-date dependency version that may contain a patch so the package author can make a proper alteration and re-upload helping the ecosystem shift-left in the rare occurrence a vulnerability is detected.

There will be cases where the author will not be able to make such changes as the changes may be out of their control and may decide to publish anyway. The banner should serve as a means of bringing awareness and helping file the appropriate security concerns to address in the next package version or hold off on publishing a version until a fix is resolved in their dependency graph.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Add a security banner for any package that might automatically run code." (#9435) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

NuGet.org should display a banner for any package that has a potential vector of `install scripts`, which is a term used for any method of running arbitrary code on install, build, or init.

A banner might look like the following:

> **Automatic Scripts**
> `init.ps1` scripts are run when the package is installed or when you open the PowerShell console.

Where the variable can be `init.ps1`, `install.ps1`, `uninstall.ps1`, MSBuild targets/task, etc and the respective behavior of when it happens (install, build, powershell init, etc)

This could be a helpful affordance for a user of unexpected behavior or potentially report a security issue to the NuGet team without having to inspect each package.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: top 100 Community packages include MSFT packages" (#9427) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: ### Impact I'm unable to use NuGet.org ### Describe the bug some Microsoft packages (specifically Xamarin ones) showing up on the galley as community ones: ... Those are not showing up when querying the `ddteldata` DS excluding the MSFT packages ([internal][query as link](https://dataexplorer.azure.com/clusters/ddteldata/databases/ClientToolsInsights?query=H4sIAAAAAAAAA23NMQvCQAyG4V3wP4TSoQURHRy7uQhaHdwl9tL22iOBXOAo+OOlUAXB9eN9+Gp/w2bEjo6SOAi6uF69wPlonhuDsyTSk9vAXQzDTzOIZ6g//JqYNIIw5IFa2y4Qqgpy9V3/XWaaelICFisW1mN8IE9FdvGNSpTWsrKcS1FHCs/pz7/hSLA/7N5FCuTRwgAAAA==)):¬† ``` NiPackageDownloads | distinct LowerId, TotalDownloads | join NiPackageOwners on $left.LowerId == $right.LowerId | where not(Owners has_any("Microsoft")) | order by TotalDownloads| take 150 ``` ### Repro Steps 1. Visit https://www.nuget.org/stats/packages 2. do not check 'Show all packages' checkbox 3. search for 'microsoft' ### Expected Behavior Microsoft packages are not part of the community overview ### Screenshots _No response_ ### Additional Context and logs _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show vulnerability/deprecation badges on packages" (#12506) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

To bring more awareness to vulnerabilities, we should add clear badges in each package list item that brings attention to them. Right now we provide an affordance that requires a developer to hover over a ‚ö†Ô∏è or click on the package to view the actual details.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/227602227-ba17abbc-ec61-4ea7-a7d5-20e2fd9bc703.png)

We should enhance this experience by putting a badge that a package has a specific status.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/227602167-f922151a-2386-4cdb-8c07-e6892d331f96.png)


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Warn package consumers when a package might automatically run code" (#12505) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

When a user is installing a package that may contain a concept of running arbitrary code on an event such as install, build, init, etc, they should be warned with a small security banner or affordance regarding the experience and when it will occur.

A banner might look like the following:

> Automatic Scripts
> init.ps1 scripts are run when the package is installed or when you open the PowerShell console.

Where the variable can be init.ps1, install.ps1, uninstall.ps1, MSBuild targets/task, etc and the respective behavior of when it happens (install, build, powershell init, etc)

This could be a helpful affordance for a user of unexpected behavior or potentially report a security issue to the NuGet team without having to install or inspect the package.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cannot create a package that has no dependencies nor content." (#12499) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Discussed in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/12498
Originally posted by **goreshmusalay** March 21, 2023 I am trying to generate NuGet package by using cPack, I am new to cmake and cpack stuff, so bare with me if the questions and doubt i have are stupid ones I am hitting the following error on issuing cpack --build . --package 1. Cannot create a package that has no dependencies nor content. I have added following NUGET params to the CMakeList.txt file. 1. CPACK_NUGET_PACKAGE_VERSION 2. CPACK_NUGET_PACKAGE_DEPENDENCIES 3. CPACK_NUGET_PACKAGE_DEBUG 4. CPACK_NUGET_PACKAGE_DESCRIPTION 5. CPACK_GENERATOR as NuGet 6. CPACK_NUGET_PACKAGE_NAME The cpack geneartes the nuget spec file but it has no tag inside it In build Dir I see folder created with the cmake install (FILES, ....) options that was added. Can you help in what must i have done wrong here?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Set CentralPackageVersionOverrideEnabled=false in project with CPM broke project restore" (#12500) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

8.0.0-preview.2.23128.3

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create project with CPM enabled. 
2. Add `<CentralPackageVersionOverrideEnabled>false</CentralPackageVersionOverrideEnabled>` to project file.
3. Run `dotnet restore`

The restore fails but does not log an error.  This is because of bad logic here: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/RestoreCommand/RestoreCommand.cs#L478

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.org migration towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure" (#60) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In the coming weeks, nuget.org will be migrating towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure that will improve the experience of our users. This change allows our team flexibility to switch to a back-up provider in the case that one CDN is down, which will broaden coverage for our users.

Some changes are coming for older TLS cipher suites, which may result in connectivity issues. From our data we believe this will affect only a small percentage of requests. We will be monitoring all feedback channels during the migration to assess impact and adjust our roll-out timeline as needed.

Below, we provide resources to determine whether you will be affected by this change. This utilizes the [.NET CLI](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/) to install a package from our pre-production (INT) environment which tests connectivity:


```
mkdir cdn-test
cd cdn-test
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package BaseTestPackage.NetStandard --source https://apiint.nugettest.org/v3/index.json
```

If you are experiencing connectivity issues while connecting to nuget.org or restoring packages from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json, such as:

"The SSL connection could not be established"

Please ensure that TLS 1.2 and any of the following cipher suites have been enabled on your machine:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256

If you have any questions, do reach out to us at‚ÄØsupport@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue:‚ÄØNuGet/Home#11058
